docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
• This course is designed to take anyone from zero to high-level FRC programmer
  • This course is based in Java
  • Software has the most aggressive learning curve of any area of FRC
  • As with any course, learning must be supplemented with practice
  • The value you get out of this is directly proportional to the effort you put in
  • The course is setup to be ready linearly from start to finish, but readers with experience are welcome to jump around
  • The goal is to teach Java, then basic FRC software, then advanced FRC software
  • Software changes fast, so always refer to updated online documentation when unsure.
  • Please enjoy! ❤️

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Familiarity with FIRST Robotics and FIRST Robotics Competition (how the program works)
  • A functional laptop/PC
  • Some time
  • A drive to learn
  • Optional: A robot with a mechanism to test with

docs.title: 1 Learn Java
docs.text: Java is a programming language Most FRC teams use Java There are alternatives - C++ - Python - LabView No alternative is more well documented online than Java Java is generally the second most popular language to Python outside of FRC The code we write runs on the Roborio (robot brain) The Roborio collects information from the sensors and sends commands to motors Alternative to Chapter 1: Learn Java -> https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-java This section will not be a comprehensive Java course, it will just cover important things for FRC

docs.title: 1.1 WPILib
docs.text: WPILib was created by WPI (Worchester Polytechnic Institute) through their partnership with FIRST Robotics The WPI Robotics Library (WPILib) is the standard software library provided for teams to write code for their FRC® robots. WPILib contains a set of useful classes and subroutines for interfacing with various parts of the FRC control system (such as sensors, motor controllers, and the driver station), as well as an assortment of other utility functions. This is code that is written for us that will make our lives easier. WPILib has documentation with a wealth of FRC Programming information.

docs.title: Enums
docs.text: Our Files are getting a little ugly We can organize them by creating folders in the src folder Drag Pet, Dog, and Cat in a pets folder Drag Building, House, and School in a buildings folder Accept the changes from Java Red Hat Red Hat added the package keyword with the name of the folder at the top of the files we moved Red Hat also added imports to App.java This tells Java where to access these classes now that they aren’t in the base directory

docs.title: 1.11: Enums
docs.text: We know how to store numbers, words, and Booleans, as well as bigger things like Students, Cats, and Dogs What about states? Like what day of the week it is or what emotion someone is feeling? This is the role of Enums Add this to your Student class near the bottom (like after the setFavoriteClass function): Now add Emotion as an instance field just like favorite class and GPA Now set emotions for your students You will need to include the class Student before using ‘Emotion.EMOTION’ to get the emotion enums. This specifies where the Emotion enums are Do the same process but for Clothes Clothing enum JEANS SWEATS SKIRT LEGGINGS SHIRT TANK_TOP There should be an instance field in student which has an array of clothes enums Before you modify App.Java with your changes, Java is a little weird… read next slide To properly create an array of clothing items, you need to import the Clothes enum To import that enum, you need to put Student.Java in a package Create a folder called ‘people’ Put Student.Java in that folder/package Now when you create an array of enums, use this format The ‘new Clothes[]’ is important because it tells Java what type of Array to create The reason we didn’t need to do that before is because we were assigning this information to objects directly Because of this, we had to specify what type of array it would be in that very line. So Java knew what array it was supposed to create: Now we are passing it directly into the constructor, so Java needs the extra info What if we want to do various things based on the current state of the enum. Like say “How are you feeling” if someone’s sad, say “I’m sorry” if they’re angry, say “Good day” if they’re happy, ect. We could use if else statements: When you put an if statement after an else, it only checks that condition if the previous condition fails This is a little ugly We can use a switch case instead: This is easier to read and less typing The switch statement checks the output of getEmotion and compares it to the cases provided If getEmotion doesn’t match any of the provided cases, it will run the default case Make sure to put ‘break’ at the end of each case This keeps Java from running the logic of the next case Ex: if you didn’t have any breaks and the case was ANGRY, it would also run the logic of HAPPY, ANXIOUS, and the default case Practice: Create method that takes a Student object as input and outputs the materials of the student’s clothes using a switch case You may need multiple methods for this Materials: Jeans: Denim Sweats: Cotton Skirt: Linen Leggings: Spandex Shirt: Cotton Tank Top: Polyester Test your method on a student Solution:

docs.title: 1.12: Math Library
docs.text: We know how to do addition, subtraction, multiplication, division What about log ln power square root minimum of two values maximum of two values Absolute value Sin Cos Tan Inverse tan Ect. Java has provided this two us through the Math class: You can also get PI and E. They are constants in the Math class Math.PI Math.E Practice: find the result of this using Java You should get ~0.5148

docs.title: 1.13: Project
docs.text: You have learned quite a few concepts You have put those individual concepts to work with practice problems Now you need to put it all together in a personal project You will likely want to create a new Java project for this so you don’t have to deal with all the files we’ve already created You can choose between 1.13.A: Wordle 1.13.B: The Price is Right Make your own project Or do both if you want extra practice Never played? Give it a try: https://www.nytimes.com/games/wordle/index.html Create a list of words Randomly choose from that list each game Have player enter a guess Tell players which letters are incorrect correct but in wrong place correct in right place Notify player if the player won Keep track of moves List of items (Do FRC components (roborio, battery), its more fun) Randomly choose an item Player inputs number of players and names Player guesses Next player guesses (ect. Until all players have guessed) Player with closes amount who doesn’t go over gets the money added to their account If they guess exactly, it’s plus $500 Print current scores each round After x rounds, the player with the most money wins

docs.title: 1.14: Suppliers
docs.text: There’s one more Java concept that is pretty integral in FRC code Let’s set up a project Create one more Java project Create a class called Clock.Java that has an integer instance field ‘ticks’ Create a ‘tick’ method that increments ‘ticks’ by one Create a ‘getTime’ method that returns ticks In App.java, create Clock object Create a new int called “currentTime” and set it to the output of the getTime method Start a while loop. Make the condition of the loop ‘true’ (so it infinitely repeats). You will be able to stop the program by pressing the red square In the while loop, tick the clock then print the current time variable Observe the result As you may have expected, we get this: Determine why this is happening The problem is that we set the variable currentTime once before the while loop and then never updated it again This means it only printed the first value we assigned to it One solution is to do update the ‘currentValue’ variable every time in the while loop Suppliers allow us to skip this step Modify the code to this: Observe results If an integer stores a number, an integer supplier stores the directions to get that number It’s like taking a picture of the empire state building and showing it to someone vs giving that person directions to see it for themselves whenever they want When Java ran into our currentTime.get() call, it actually went and reran clock.getTime() to find the latest value There are a couple key syntax updates to keep in mind We use Supplier<[Return Type]> to create the specific type of Supplier Note that I used Integer rather than int because Java expects an object, not a primitive in the “<>” The double colon tells java that we want a supplier of a method rather than the output of the method When we want to run the code that the supplier is pointing to, we call ‘.get()’ Suppliers can handle parameters as well, but when defining the supplier use the “() ->” format Here is an FRC example: You want a section of code to run when you press a button In that way you want the code to be run every time you press the button, not just once at the start of the program Suppliers are helpful for this

docs.title: 1.2: Install VSCode
docs.text: VSCode is an IDE (Integrated development environment) It's like Microsoft Word, but for code VSCode is the only IDE supported by WPILib WPILib has a special version of VSCode - Includes extra tools for FRC teams Download here (or search “Install WPILib”): https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/zero-to-robot/step-2/wpilib-setup.html Click on the “Extensions” button on the left side of the screen Install “Extension Pack for Java” This will help with testing Java code You may need to reload window No need to install a JDK (already installed with WPILib VSCode) You can close out of the welcome screen

docs.title: 1.3: First Java Program
docs.text: Create a new folder called “LearnFRC” and open it in VSCode (file -> open folder) Press ctrl+shift+p, this will open your command pallete type “Java: Create new Java project…” No build tools Name it “Workspace” New window opens Close the old window Open Source -> App Press “Run” above the main method Observe output in terminal Congrats, you ran your first Java program Practice: Make it print “Hello, FRC World” System.out.println() is the code to print to the console in Java Ignore the “public class App” and “public static void main…” for now. What’s important is that the code inside the purple brackets is run when we press “run”

docs.title: 1.4: Variables
docs.text: Variables are how we store information Add a line before the print line like this example: Then replace the inside of println() with just the word text (no quotations) Run the program, observe the output. Here is the structure of this new line: The word ‘text’ is the name Note: the semicolon indicates the end of that line. You need one after every statement in java. (its like a period in English). Practice: change the variable name to ‘words’ with the program still working

docs.title: 1.4.1: Types
docs.text: ‘String’ is the type of variable. String means the content of the variable is text. Here are some other variable types: int: a whole number double: a number than can have decimals boolean: a true or false char: a single character Here is the logic with a boolean instead of a String: Practice: make it print your favorite number using a variable

docs.title: 1.4.2: Operations
docs.text:
Operations are like math. They are one way we can process information. Here is an example: Here are other operations: ‘-’ : subtraction ‘*’: multiplication ‘/’: division ‘%’ : modulo Practice: make your code multiply two double variables x (5.5) and y (9.1) and print the result When dividing two integers, the result will always be the natural quotient with it’s decimals cut off This is called truncation (because the output also has to be an integer, which can’t have decimals). Try running this: Now change the types to doubles and observe the result Strings can also be added. Change your variables to be Strings and add them together in the println(). You can also add booleans, ints, and doubles to strings and they string will be appended with the content of the other var Another type of operation is comparison Change x and y to be integers, then change the inside of the println to be x==y Now make x and y the same number There are other comparisons:

= <=

< != These comparisons turn 2 of any variable into a boolean Practice: make a new variable called ‘output’ ‘output’ should store whether x >= y Print output Booleans have their own set of operations || : if either boolean is true, output is true, otherwise false && : if either boolean is false, output is false, otherwise true !: negates the following boolean Ex: Try recreating this and running it: Practice: Now make the program print whether int x is greater than 0 and less than 10 Ex: Try recreating this and running it: Practice: make a program that prints x times x, then prints the opposite boolean of whether x times x is less than 20 Syntactic sugar (makes life easier) x+=y x-=y x=y x/=y These are the same as x=x+y x=x-y x=xy x=x/y Example: Output is 3. Practice: change x and y to Strings (any Strings). Observe results. You can also add 1 and subtract 1 (increment, and decrement) x++ x-- Ex: Practice: make it subtract 1 instead of add 1 to x

docs.title: 1.5: Logic
docs.text: Logic statements allows us to create more complex code Some logic statements if else for While These will be explained in this chapter

docs.title: 1.5.1: if
docs.text: if while run code on a condition. If the condition isn’t met, the code is skipped. Run this: Then this (flip the less than sign to greater than): - Practice: make it only print if x divided by y is greater than 1 and less than 10 You can add else after the ‘}’ of the if statement to run something if the condition is false

docs.title: 1.5.2: else
docs.text: Practice: make x and y Booleans Print “yay” if they are equal Print “nay” if they are not equal (using else) ‘for’ is how we repeat code Example: Functionality Step 1: Java will assign ‘i’ to zero (assignment) Step 2: Java will check whether i is less than 10 (comparison) True: continue False: exit Step 3: java will add 1 to I (increment) That code prints 0 through 9 because when i = 10, it fails the condition i < 10 Now change the code to print [0, 2, 4, … , 18] Practice Now write another integer y before the if statement Set it to 4 Make the condition if y times i is not equal to y times 5 Make the increment i++ Try to understand what the result means while is like a simpler version of for. Loops through values. Every time it checks a condition. If the condition is false, the loop exits. Ex: Practice: make it print 0 to -7

docs.title: 1.6: Arrays
docs.text: Write this out:That’s a lot of code for something fairly simple There’s a better way Instead, we do this: Same result, less writing. In general, this is a good goal in programming. In this case we used an array. The little ‘[]’ after int indicate to Java that it is an array of integers, rather than a single integer. The ‘{‘ and ‘}’ with elements separated by commas indicate the creation of an array numbers.length returns the number of elements When trying to access an element of an array, we use numbers[i] This tells java that we want the element at location i Important: the location or index of an element in an array starts at 0 and increases. For example, 2 is at index 0, 3 is at index 2… Practice: Modify the array to be an array of Strings Practice: Only print the element if ‘i’ is 0 or 2. Otherwise print “Skipping…” Here is another way to create an array: This creates a String array of length 4. Currently nothing is stored in the array. We can fix that by accessing elements and assigning Strings: Practice: try printing these words in reverse order using a for loop

docs.title: 1.6.1: enhanced for loop
docs.text: • Enhanced for loops are more syntactic sugar. You don’t need enhanced for loops but they make life easier. Ex: Enhanced for loop is for iterating through arrays Note: You can’t modify elements of an array with an enhanced for loop Note: I didn’t have brackets after the for loop because I only had one line of code inside the array Practice: make a double array Use an enhanced for loop to print out whether each element is greater than 10 Practice: make a double array Use an enhanced for loop to print out whether each element is greater than 10 ArrayLists also make life easier. You can’t add an element to an array past it’s length The array is not dynamically sized (remember with size 5, there are elements [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]. There is no index 5.) ArrayLists allow you to make the array bigger or smaller easily They also work with enhanced for loops Note: you need to add the import statement at the top to tell Java you want to use the ArrayList library This is useful because in the real world we don’t know how many elements there will be. For example, there could be two game pieces showing on the camera, or there could be five. A statically sized array may not work. Practice: initialize an empty string arraylist Use a for loop to fill 5 elements with 100 minus the index of that element squared Use an enhanced for loop to print all values in the list

docs.title: 1.7: Methods
docs.text: Methods allow us to reuse logic without having to type it out again Methods can have inputs and outputs Lets make one! Write this code: ‘operation’ takes two integers as input and outputs an integer. Here is the formatting: Visibility: explained later. Stick to ‘public’ for now Static: explained later. Stick to ‘static’ for now Return type, the type of value you get out of the method Name: name used to call (run) the method Inputs: what you put into the method. The method can process the inputs to produce the output Even the ‘main’ method is a method. It is called by Java when you press ‘run’ Nearly all code lives inside methods Practice: Make a method that takes a string as input and outputs that string with a space after it Make a method that combines 3 strings using that first method Make a method that takes in 3 strings, prints the output of the 2nd method with those strings, then prints whether the length of the output of the 2nd method is greater than 10 (using String.length) Hint: assign the output of the second method to a variable Run the third method with 3 Strings of your choice in main You can also have methods that don’t output anything. To do this, make the return type ‘void’. - You can also have methods that don’t require an input:

docs.title: 1.8: Scanner
docs.text: Scanner is a way for us to type text into the console, which will put that text into our program. We don’t use Scanner in FRC because it would be silly to be typing information into our computers during a match rather than using a controller It is a useful tool for learning Java Here is an example: I typed “Hi!” into the console, the program said what I typed. Again, we need to import Scanner so Java knows we want those libraries The scanner is its own variable type You can create a scanner object by running “new Scanner(System.in)” Once you create the scanner, you can use scanner.nextLine to get a String from what the user put into the console It’s good practice to write scanner.close at the end of the program to prevent a memory leak - Practice: Create an integer and assign it to some value Allow the user to guess a number If it’s too large, print “Too Large” and allow them to guess again If it’s too small, print “Too Small” and allow them to guess again If it is correct, print “You win, that took x tries” If you want to go above and beyond, use java.util.Random and random.nextInt to generate random game numbers

docs.title: Classes
docs.text: Generally, each Java file corresponds to a class For example, we are working in App.Java and the class App We can create a new class by creating a new file Right click on the “src” folder and create a new file called “Student.java” Java will autofill this: Let’s write a method in Student and run that method in App: You need to specify Student.addNumbers so that Java knows where to look to find addNumbers since it isn’t in the App class The addNumbers method in Student is ‘public’ so that outside classes can call it. If it was ‘private’ it would only be accessible inside the Student class Practice: create a method for cubing a number in Student.java and run it in App.java

docs.title: 1.9.1: Objects
docs.text: You can also use these new classes to create new variable types Java needs instructions on how to create a new variable type This is called a constructor The constructor is a method that outputs an object of the type of its class The name of the constructor needs to match the class Constructors should be public You don’t need to write static or a return type in constructors Instance fields are variables that are specific to a single object Instance fields are created outside of methods Lets add some: There are a couple problems here Instance fields usually shouldn’t be accessed directly We can add ‘private’ to clarify they should only be accessible inside the class Another issue is that these instance fields are going to be the same for every Student object we create, we want each student to have a different favorite class and GPA To fix this, we can add arguments (parameters/inputs) to the constructor. Like this: Theres a problem here too though We’re trying to set our instance fields to the parameters But because they have the same names, Java isn’t sure which ones we mean so it always defaults to the parameters To fix this, we can add ‘this.’ to the instance fields to clarify that we are referring to the instance fields Now we should remove the assignments to “Chemistry” and 3 because they will be assigned later The variables will be assigned in the constructor Now we can modify App.java to include the Student information The problem is, there’s no way to access or modify the student information The solution is getters and setters

docs.title: 1.9.1.1: Getters
docs.text: A getter is a method that outputs an instance field from a class: There is no “static” behind getters When there is the word static, that means you can run it by calling [class name].[method name] But when static doesn’t exist, you must create (or instantiate) an object of the type of that class. Then you call [object name].[method name]. Example: Practice: Create a getter for GPA Print the GPA of the student objects in App.java

docs.title: 1.9.1.2: Setters
docs.text: Sometimes we want to change instance fields After all: Students’ favorite classes change all the time Students’ GPA changes all the time The same applies to FRC. You may want to get the velocity of your shooter, or you may want to set the velocity of your shooter. A setter doesn’t have a return type because you aren’t getting anything back. You are just changing something. So the return type is ‘void’. A setter does have an argument because you want to tell the object what to change the instance field to. Ex: Again, we need to use ‘this.’ because we have two variables named ‘favoriteClass’, the instance field and the parameter. Now in App.java Practice: create a setter for GPA Modify the values in App.java Print the modified values

docs.title: 1.9.2: Inheritance
docs.text: Inheritance is useful when you want to create multiple types that share properties For example, a Dog class and a Cat class would share properties such as name and diet, but petting each animal may result in different outcomes Dog might also have a walkLength attribute Cat might also have a sleepLength attribute To remedy this in Java, we can have a Pet class that has the stuff shared between pets and then extend the Pet class with Cat or Dog specific stuff. Create a Pet file and class that has instance fields name and diet Include getters and setters for name and diet Include a method called “pet”, that prints “Your pet is happy” Create a Dog file and class: The word ‘extends’ means the Dog class is an extension of the Pet class and therefore inherits methods from Pet ‘super()’ refers to the constructor of the Pet class. When we run the Dog constructor, it calls the Pet constructor and gives the Dog the name and diet information Now add an instance field to Dog for walkLength and include a getter and setter Now, we can test this In App.java, Create a Pet object and a Dog object Call ‘pet’ Call ‘getDiet’ on both and print the result Call ‘getWalkLength’ on the Dog object and print the result Under the hood, the Dog object is actually also a Pet object. It just has extra functionality. Now Create a Cat class Overrides Pet Includes extra instance field: sleepLength Create a Cat object in App.java Call ‘pet’ Print result of ‘getDiet’ Print result of ‘getSleepLength’ Now we can “override” the ‘pet’ method of Pet in Cat To do this, add a ‘pet’ method in Dog Make it print “Purrrr……” Run the program again, observe the output of ‘pet’ on the cat Now Create a Cat class Overrides Pet Includes extra instance field: sleepLength Create a Cat object in App.java Call ‘pet’ Print result of ‘getDiet’ Print result of ‘getSleepLength’ Now we can “override” the ‘pet’ method of Pet in Cat To do this, add a ‘pet’ method in Dog Make it print “Purrrr……” Run the program again, observe the output of ‘pet’ on the cat Now add Pet as an instance field to Student Give one of your student objects a cat Give one of your student objects a dog Pet one of the student’s animals by calling [student object].[get pet].pet()

docs.title: 1.9.3: Implementation
docs.text: Sometimes we don’t need a default method (like Pet having the ‘pur’ method with logic for “Your pet is happy”) For example, there may be blueprints to build a house, there may be blueprints to build a school. Building a “building” is so vague that there aren’t blueprints to build a generic building Make a Building class, a School class, and a House class To accomplish what we are describing, change Building to be an Interface: Now add ‘implements Building’ to the House class Now add a ‘build’ method to the Building interface Java doesn’t like it because by adding brackets, we implied that we have added functionality to build in the Building interface Remember, Building shouldn’t have any logic for ‘build’ Remove the brackets Now add a keyword: ‘abstract’ This tells Java that the build method is not meant to be a standalone method of Building, but a method that will be overridden in child classes In House there is now an error Hover over the error Click “quick fix” Click “add unimplemented methods” When you implement an interface, you need to include its methods Otherwise, there wouldn’t be any logic The ‘@Override’ text before the ‘build’ method makes sure Java overrides the abstract method in Building Now we can replace the logic with printing “Building House” Follow this same process for School Because neither School or House have a constructor, Java gives them an implicit constructor Now create a Building array with one House and one School inside of it Use an enhanced for loop to iterate over that array calling build on each object You should get different outputs for each object

docs.title: 1.9.4: Subclasses
docs.text: Subclasses are pretty simple Create a class called “Constants” In that class, create a class called “ElevatorConstants” and “ShooterConstants” Add these variables: They are public because we want other classes to be able to access this information They are static because we don’t want to instantiate an ElevatorConstants object to access the elevator height, we just want to access it directly They are final so that they cannot be changed later. They are constants after all. They are in all caps to clarify they are constants In App.java, print the elevator height
