docs.title: 2 GitHub
docs.text: The Java files you have been working on are stored in your computer Now imagine those Java files are your robot code Also consider that you have teammates who want to contribute as well How do you allow everyone to work on the code? One option could be to have everyone work on your computer This would be a huge bottleneck because only one person would be able to work at a time Also you would need to give your computer to others for them to work on the code Another option could be to email all the files to all your teammates and have them work on their own systems Now you have multiple different versions of the code Which code do you actually use? The solution is GitHub GitHub is cloud storage for coding projects You can upload your project to the cloud and teammates can download their own copies to develop with Once your teammates have developed new code, they can upload those changes to the central cloud version The truth is that it’s a little more complicated than that Hence the addition of this chapter to the guide

docs.title: 2.1 Create Account
docs.text: To use GitHub, first you need to create an account Visit this link: https://github.com/signup

docs.title: 2.2 Install Git
docs.text: Git is the computer program that will tell your computer how to store GitHub projects and how to pull and push to the cloud Visit this link: https://git-scm.com/downloads

docs.title: 2.3 GitHub Organization
docs.text: Your team should have an organization on GitHub You can join the organization to contribute to your team’s projects If your team doesn’t have an organization, your team should create one: https://docs.github.com/en/organizations/collaborating-with-groups-in-organizations/creating-a-new-organization-from-scratch

docs.title: 2.4 Repository
docs.text: Repositories are basically codebases/projects Each robot will have its own repository with code specific to that robot Have your organization create a training repository If you are working by yourself, you can also just create a repo on your GitHub account Make it public and empty and name it something like “SoftwareTraining” https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-repositories/quickstart-for-repositories

docs.title: 2.5 Cloning
docs.text: The next step is to download a local copy of the repo It is possible to download a zip file with the repo files inside of it, but this won’t link back to the cloud repo Instead, we do what’s called “cloning” Follow the images Go into VSCode Press ctrl+shift+p or cmd+shift+p This will open the “command pallet” Type “clone” Click “Git: Clone” (this will only work if Git is installed and you’ve restarted VSCode) Paste the link and hit enter Choose where to store it (most people create a GitHub folder in Documents and store GitHub projects in there)

docs.title: 2.6 Branches
docs.text: Suppose you want to write the code for the robot intake A friend wants to write the code of the autonomous You both download local copies and work on code Now you both try to upload your local copies to the main repo Who’s copy wins? Whoever uploads first will get their code on the main codebase Whoever is second will get their change rejected to prevent overwriting person A’s change Suppose you want to write the code for the robot intake A friend wants to write the code of the autonomous You both download local copies and work on code Now you both try to upload your local copies to the main repo Who’s copy wins? Whoever uploads first will get their code on the main codebase Whoever is second will get their change rejected to prevent overwriting person A’s change The solution is branches Branches are variants of the main codebase for specific development These variants are also stored both on the cloud and on local machines It’s like timeline variants in the TV show Loki Now person A can create an “intake” branch for their work and Person B can make an “autonomous” branch for their’s Both people can develop independently on their own branches When they feel done, they can do a ‘merge’ back into the master branch (this will be explained later) You are currently in the “master” branch (the main development branch) At competition, the master branch is usually what's deployed to the robot To create a branch, click on where it says “master” Then click “create new branch” Name the branch your name Press the cloud button next to your name in the bottom left to upload it to Github Now everyone create a file called “[Your name].Java” Write an instance field and a constructor Make sure to save Check the third tab on the left for your change: Here is where you can review your changes before shipping them to the cloud codebase To push this change to the cloud version of your branch, hover over [Your Name].Java and press the little plus button This stages your change Now write a message specifying what change you made in the message box Press “Commit” Now the local copy of your GitHub branch on your computer has acknowledged your change, but we still haven’t gotten it to the cloud yet To push this change to the cloud version of your branch, hover over [Your Name].Java and press the little plus button This stages your change Now write a message specifying what change you made in the message box Press “Commit” Now the local copy of your GitHub branch on your computer has acknowledged your change, but we still haven’t gotten it to the cloud yet To push this change to the cloud version of your branch, hover over [Your Name].Java and press the little plus button This stages your change Now write a message specifying what change you made in the message box Press “Commit” Now the local copy of your GitHub branch on your computer has acknowledged your change, but we still haven’t gotten it to the cloud yet To push and pull from the cloud, press the little next to the name of your branch Now go back to the GitHub repo Click the ‘branches’ button Open your branch You should see your changes Now we want to get those changes back into the master branch To do this, go to the ‘Pull Requests’ tab in GitHub The arrow indicates where to code is coming from and going to Make sure the one on the right is your branch Press “Create Pull Request” Name the pull request and give a description Usually, a teammate would look at your pull request by going to the pull request tab and clicking on your pull request Here they can review the history of that branch and make comments They can go to the “Files Changed” tab and look at everything that is different between the new branch and the master branch From here they can hover over a line of code and comment on it, starting a review If they are satisfied with the PR they can go to the main page and approve the changes and even make the merge happen The person merging should also delete the branch unless given other instructions by the owner of the branch After all, the development is done, there is no point in keeping the branch If you are working alone, press ‘Merge’. This will send your code to the main codebase. Then delete the new branch. If you are in a group, find a partner (or make a group of three) Review they’re changes If you are in a group, make sure everyone isn’t trying to merge into main all at once Have one person merge, then the next, and so on Each person should delete the branch they merge Now the master branch has everyone’s contributions

docs.title: 2.7 README.md
docs.text: Many GitHub repos have a README.md file in them This is a file in markdown format: https://www.markdownguide.org/basic-syntax/ It will display the markdown when people visit your GitHub repo https://github.com/FRC-Sonic-Squirrels/2024-Robot-Code?tab=readme-ov-file

docs.title: 2.8 Issues
docs.text: During a season there are often many things happening or planned Write elevator code Fix that drivetrain bug Add a README Refactor autonomous code Issues allow us to store information of what is being worked on and what needs to change To Create an issue, go to the ‘Issues’ tab in GitHub Name the issue and give a description (can be anything) Issues don’t have to be literal issues/problems, they can be new things you want to add or modifications you want to make On the right, under ‘assignees’ press “assign yourself” This is very important when you are developing on a project with multiple people If you don’t assign yourself to an issue and start working on it, your friend might start working on that same issue and now we’re wasting time You can also link branches to issues so people know where the development is happening This option can be found in the bottom right You can also label issues as ‘bugs’, ‘enhancements’, and ‘good first issues’ on the right Give your issue a label You can even create new labels like ‘high-priority’ or ‘subsystem’ or ‘command’: https://docs.github.com/en/issues/using-labels-and-milestones-to-track-work/managing-labels If you are working in a group, find someone else’s issue Write a comment saying you completed it (pretend you completed it) Close the issue

docs.title: 2.9 Rebases
docs.text: When we merged our branches into main, GitHub knew how to combine each branch so that everyone’s files were added This is called an automatic merge Automatic merges are not always possible  For example, what if two people made unrelated changes to the same file We can merge manually One person create a file called “Robot.Java” in the master branch Create instance field height and a constructor Commit that directly to the master branch (usually don’t do this in FRC because all code should be reviewed) If you are with other programmers find a partner (or group of three) create a new branch off main for your whole group (combine initials for the name) Now have two members create new branches off that (using first initial, last name for branch names) You can create a branch off of a specific branch using “Create Branch From” in command pallete If you are alone, create two branches off master, one called “a” another called “b” Now on one of the new branches, add instance field ‘weight’ (make sure to add that as a parameter for the constructor) On the other branch, create instance field ‘name’ Merge the ‘weight’ branch into the branch it came from using a pull request Do not merge into master if you are in a group Now, try doing the same process with the ‘name’ branch You should be unable to automatically merge Go back into VSCode, open command pallete, hit “rebase branch” Make sure to rebase it using the branch it came from A Rebase is essentially a manual merge but fancier Rebases are like taking the things that happened on the central branch while you’ve been busy working on the new development branch and putting them behind the changes on the development branch - It’s like if on timeline A you played Minecraft and on timeline B you ate a hamburger, merging them with a rebase would mean you played Minecraft, then ate a hamburger When you rebase, try to include both changes where possible so that in the end, both instance fields are there, they both are passed through the constructor, and they both have all their getters and setters This is a simple rebase With larger code bases, they get much more complicated It takes practice Once the rebase has completed, commit the changes from it Now you can automatically merge

docs.title: 3 Subsystems
docs.text: When you think of any FRC robot you can always split it into distinct elements Drivebase Intake Elevator Arm Shooter 2930 2024 Robot Cad: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/bbdb71fe91301c3d3bc1c45c/w/39c25dbe908c4708e0ef4712/e/f18b60a8ce66dd0b64a1acaa Full robot: Drivebase: Intake: Elevator: Arm: End Effector: Shooter: Remember how we represented Students, Houses, and Dogs with Java classes? We do the same for Intakes, Elevators, and Drivebases

docs.title: 3.1 Robot Projects
docs.text: Like before, we need to create a Java project for our robot However, this time we need it to take advantage of all the stuff WPILib has given us Ability to talk to the roborio Libraries to communicate with xbox controllers Configuration Extra important stuff Instead of creating a basic Java project, we will create a Robot project Make a new repo on your personal GitHub called FRCSoftwareTraining Clone the repo Open command pallete Hit “WPILib: Create a new project” Fill the info like on the right (make sure to make the base folder your repo and the project name is exactly the same as the folder of your repo) You should end up with something like this Commit everything with a message like ‘init’ Congrats, you now have a robot codebase!

docs.title: 3.2 Subsystem Class
docs.text: Enter the src folder Then open java/frc/robot There is a lot going on here, but there is a folder for subsystems At this point, if you have a robot with a mechanism, choose the simplest subsystem on that robot (not the drivetrain, not a turret) Elevators and shooters are ideal If you don’t have a robot/mechanism, find a robot online and pretend you are coding its mechanism Whatever subsystem you chose probably falls into one of three categories Identify the category your subsystem fits into (even if it isn’t on the list) Some subsystems are purely voltage control (like grabbers in pick and place games) These are far simpler than other types of mechanisms, I would advise choosing a different subsystem Sometimes subsystems combine categories Ex: 2930’s 2024 Shooter Combines angular position control (pivot) Angular velocity control (flywheels) Ex: 2910’s 2023 and 2025 Arm Combines angular position control (pivot) Linear position control (extender) Angular position control (wrist) For now we’ll try to avoid subsystems that combine multiple degrees of freedom (ways it can move) If needed, you can focus on one degree of freedom of a subsystem that has multiple During build season, focus on coding the most important subsystems first (drivetrain, intake, scoring mech) Right now, focus on coding the simplest subsystems first The first step is to right click on the subsystems folder and hit “Create a New Class or Command,” then hit subsystem Give your subsystem an adequate name for the engineering term that describes that mechanism (don’t put “Subsystem” after the main word)

docs.title: 3.3 Subsystem Structure
docs.text: You will notice there is some pre-generated code There is a constructor and a ‘periodic’ method This class is extending ‘SubsystemBase’ There are some cool technical details behind how this works, but what is important is that ‘periodic’ will be called 50 times per second by a background process. This allows us to put repeating code in the periodic method and one-time code in the contructor

docs.title: 3.4 Closed Loop
docs.text: There is an important engineering concept we must understand before diving into any subsystem The Closed Loop Feedback Control System (or Feedback Loop) This is also known as a PID (Proportional Integral Derivative) Loop On the next slide is a clip from a Mark Rober video that demonstrates how humans do this https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LEZCxxKp0hM Similar to how Feedback loops power drones, robot dogs, and jets, they are critical to FRC Robots In fact, feedback loops control the motion of elevators, arms, drivetrains, and most other subsystems One distinctive factor between a great team and good team is how quickly and smoothly they can control the motion of their robot Watch this video of 1690 Orbit’s 2025 autonomous Focus on how smoothly their mechanisms move https://www.youtube.com/shorts/p8AGxqX46m8 The big question is how do they work At the end of the day, your mechanism is at point A and you want it to be at point B in the least amount of time (this is different for velocity control, we’ll get into that) The problem that control loops solve is knowing what to tell the motor based on the position of the mechanism Take an elevator for example The Height is 0 inches You want it to be at 40 inches One approach would be to just give the motor positive voltage However, eventually the elevator would keep going past the desired position Another approach would be to give it positive voltage until it reaches the desired pos However, in the real world, mechanisms can’t go from some velocity to zero in no time This means we would still overshoot The real solution is to send voltage to the motor based on the difference between desired and current position (in this case 20) However, 20 volts exceeds the max of 12 in FRC So we add a scaling factor called ‘P’ that we multiply by the 20 Lets say P is 0.5 Now at the bottom, we are giving 10 volts to the motor: (20-0)0.5 Half way up, we give the motor 5 volts (20-10)0.5 And when we are one inch away, we give the motor 0.5 volts (20-19)*0.5 This reduces the chance of overshooting dramatically However, overshooting is still a risk The idea behind a PID is that you put in a bogus value for P (usually really low like 0.01) You observe how quickly the mechanism reaches its goal (usually pretty slowly at first) You increase or decrease P until you get a smooth motion ‘I’ and ‘D’ are also numbers you can play with for smooth motion They involve some calculus that you don’t need to understand to tune a PID Usually, my team doesn’t touch I, and we only use D when we are trying to prevent overshoot Do what works for your robot The reality is PIDs are a little more complicated than what we’ve discussed Gravity is also a factor This means that the elevator carriage will get to a point where the motor output is equal to gravity and it will be below its desired position In this case, we often add a constant fudge factor (also known as a feed forward) to our final voltage so that the elevator is always counteracting gravity You can imagine that this same concept can apply to the angle of an arm When we talk about velocity, there’s a current velocity and a target velocity. It’s similar, but different math applies. Thankfully, the math for PIDs is usually done for us by the motors (or motor controllers) themselves. We just need to set the P, I, and D values More info on PIDs: https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/introduction/introduction-to-pid.html

docs.title: 3.5 Motor Object
docs.text: Similar to how we have Java classes/objects for Subsystems, we need a class for motors Lucky for us, this coding has already been done by companies like REV Robotics and CTRE Figure out which company made your motor/motor controller (if its not on the chart, look it up): https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/can-devices/third-party-devices.html If your team is deciding between motor options for your next season I would always say shoot for Kraken X60s or Kraken X44s even at a higher price point The CTRE ecosystem is very user friendly Advanced motion control software These motors have incredible performance. All of the top teams use them because of this. Neo 550s may be $30, but the motor controller you need to control them is $100 (2025 numbers) If its CTRE, you likely use a TalonFX motor object: https://api.ctr-electronics.com/phoenix6/release/java/com/ctre/phoenix6/hardware/TalonFX.html If its REV, you likely use a Spark MAX motor object: https://codedocs.revrobotics.com/java/com/revrobotics/spark/sparkmax It could also be a Talon SRX, Victor SPX, or SPARK Flex You will need to use the API Documentation corresponding to your motor for the following slides Before we can create a motor object, we need to install the vendor libraries for that motor To do this, go to the vendor dependencies tab on the left sidebar in VSCode Install CTRE Pheonix-6 or REVLib Before creating a motor object, we need the device ID or CAN ID (if you don’t have a robot, make it up!) To find the CAN ID, you will need to open the software for your vendor For CTRE it is called Pheonix Tuner X (very nice software) For REV it is called the REV Hardware Client Download this software, open it, and power on your robot For CTRE you can just connect to your robot’s network For REV you will need to connect to your PDH or motor controller via USB In the software you should see a list of motors/motor controllers/sensors If they aren’t named, you can usually ‘blink’ motors by pressing a ‘blink’ button This will make the LED on the motor blink so you can tell which motor is which You will also be able to view and modify CAN IDs here Make sure each motor has a unique CAN ID Note down the CAN ID(s) for the motor(s) for your specific mechanism Go back to your code and open Constants.Java Create a subclass called “CanIDs” Create a constant for your CAN ID Now create an instance field in your subsystem for you motor object The parameter of the motor constructor should be the constant of the CAN ID Keep in mind, some motors are not connected to the default Can Bus Some are on a separate CAN loop such as a CANivore If you are unsure about this, ask someone who worked on the electronics on your team If the motor is not on the main CAN bus, you will need to specify the CAN bus name in the motor constructor as well (the name can be found in the vendor software) In the subsystem constructor, you will have to configure the motor The best practice on this vary by vendor (see documentation) Typically, you want to configure: Motor invert (if you don’t know, you can find out later by running the motor carefully) Current limit (this will come back to bite you later if you don’t set it. Generally aim for 30 amps. CTRE docs on this.) Neutral mode should be set to brake (when not in brake mode, mechanisms will go limp) Configuring PID constants will be discussed later CTRE example: Note that kG is the feed forward that resists gravity If you are using MotionMagic, you will also need to tune acceleration and cruise velocity later Some mechanisms have two (or more; looking at you 2910) motors powering the same element (this allows for snappier motion) If this is the case: define another motor Call the first one “lead” Call the second one “follower” In the constructor, configure the follower to be a follower to the lead (vendors make it easy to do this, it’s usually a simple configuration) Sometimes the motors need to rotate in opposite directions to power the same mechanism In this case, make sure to set them as inverted in the configuration It’s good practice to have a setVoltage method in every subsystem This way, you can set the voltage to 0 when necessary Create the setVoltage method with a ‘volts’ parameter and find your motor object’s setVoltage method and call it in your setVoltage method

docs.title: 3.6 Creating a Subsystem
docs.text: Go to the corresponding section for the subsystem you chose 3.6.A: Linear Mechanism (Elevator, ect.) 3.6.B: Angular Pos Mechanism (Arm, ect.) 3.6.C: Angular Vel Mechanism (Intake, ect.) Do one mechanism, then move onto the Advantage Kit/Scope chapter and Commands chapter before writing another one If your mechanism is differential, I would suggest avoiding this as your first subsystem. Here is a phoenix 6 class used for diffy mechs: https://api.ctr-electronics.com/phoenix6/release/java/com/ctre/phoenix6/mechanisms/DifferentialMechanism.html For the linear mechanism slides I am going to refer to an elevator If you aren’t using an elevator, replace where I say ‘height’ with ‘displacement’ and where I say ‘elevator’ with whatever your mechanism is You may or may not need to deal with gravity depending on the angle of your linear mechanism Set your PID to a low P (0.02) and 0 for I and D for now in the constructor where you configure the motor If using CTRE, also set motion magic config: https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/latest/docs/api-reference/device-specific/talonfx/motion-magic.html Now we need a method to set the height of the elevator (specifically, the height of the carriage of the elevator. If you don’t know what that means, ask the person who designed your elevator) There is usually a method of the motor object you can call to set the motor position For CTRE, you need to give it a control request. There are multiple options for this, but I would suggest a ‘MotionMagicVoltage’ request When you give the motor a number, you are not telling it what height the elevator should go to (the motor doesn’t know it’s attached to an elevator) Instead, you give it motor rotations This means that if we want a method that takes in the height as a parameter, we need to convert height to motor rotations There are two import factors in this conversion, winch (or pulley) circumference and gear ratio This is generally the formula you will use for the conversion (pulley and winch diameters are interchangeable mathematically) Put these constants in your ElevatorConstants class in Constants You will most likely need to talk to the designer of your robot arm to get the gear ratio Note that ‘INCHES_TO_MOTOR_ROT’ should be multiplied by the number of inches you want the elevator reach to get the number of motor rotations Now write the method to set the height of the elevator It should take in the height you want the elevator to go to It should scale that to the rotations the motor should go to It should tell the motor to go to that position Quick safety measure: add a constant for your elevator max height (make sure to label the constant as being in inches) Use MathUtil.clamp to clamp the inches parameter between 0 and the max height This will prevent your elevator from trying to go to an unreasonable position If you know how, you might even want to log a warning when the height is being clamped (or use System.out.println()) We will discuss how to log warnings later CTRE example: The core functionality is now done. In theory, we should be able to move the elevator There is still an issue When the motor wakes up after you turn on the robot, it assumes it is at zero position Sometimes, the robot can be turned on when the motor is not at zero position In this situation, we need a way to tell the elevator motor that it is at zero position after turning it on (this is typically called “zeroing”. One might say “I zeroed the robot; we are ready for the match”) Some robots use Time of Flight (ToF) sensors to sense the position of the elevator at all times. If your robot has one, you can ignore it for now, but you may want to add that functionality in later. Most motors have a setPosition or a setSensorPosition method Make a method in your Elevator class called ‘resetSensorPosition’ Make it set the motor/sensor position to zero Another method you may want is ‘setNeutralMode’ with a parameter for the neutral mode (brake or coast) This will set the motor config to have a selected neutral mode This is very useful for when a technician wants to freely move a robot mechanism around while the robot is disabled Write the ‘setNeutralMode’ method Here is an example of the setNeutralMode method for CTRE It returns a boolean for whether the status of the motor is okay For the angular position mechanism slides I am going to refer to an arm If you aren’t using an arm, replace where I say ‘arm’ with whatever your mechanism is Set your PID to a low P (0.02) and 0 for I and D for now in the constructor where you configure the motor If using CTRE, also set motion magic config: https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/latest/docs/api-reference/device-specific/talonfx/motion-magic.html Now we need a method to set the angle of the arm There is usually a method of the motor object you can call to set the motor position For CTRE, you need to give it a control request. There are multiple options for this, but I would suggest a ‘MotionMagicVoltage’ request Add a GEAR_RATIO constant to an ArmConstants class in Constants You will most likely need to talk to the designer of your robot arm to get the gear ratio You can configure your motor to know what the gear ratio is: This allows us to put in the arm angle we want into the ‘setControl’ motor method Now write the method to set the angle of the arm For the parameter of the angle, use a Rotation2d object It should tell the motor to go to that position Quick safety measure: Most arms have a min and max angle (unless there is a turret involved) If so, add Rotation2d constants for the min and max angle (you get to choose where Ѳ=0°) Clamp the angle parameter of the method using MathUtil.clamp This will prevent your arm from trying to go to an unreasonable position If you know how, you might even want to log a warning when the angle is being clamped (or use System.out.println()) We will discuss how to log warnings later If your angular position mechanism doesn’t have a min and max angle (aka it’s a turret): You can pretend the min and max angles are 0 and 360 degrees for now, or Try continuous wrap with CTRE: https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/stable/docs/api-reference/device-specific/talonfx/closed-loop-requests.html REV Robotics most likely has similar functionality CTRE example: The core functionality is now done. In theory, we should be able to turn the arm There is still an issue When the motor wakes up after you turn on the robot, it assumes it is at zero position Sometimes, the robot can be turned on when the motor is not at zero position In this situation, we need a way to tell the arm motor where zero actually is (this is typically called “zeroing”. One might say “I zeroed the robot; we are ready for the match”) The core functionality is now done. In theory, we should be able to turn the arm There is still an issue When the motor wakes up after you turn on the robot, it assumes it is at zero position Sometimes, the robot can be turned on when the motor is not at zero position In this situation, we need a way to tell the arm motor where zero actually is (this is typically called “zeroing”. One might say “I zeroed the robot; we are ready for the match”) Some mechanisms use magnetic encoders which can keep track of the mechanism position even after the robot is turned off: https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/stable/docs/hardware-reference/cancoder/index.html This is why you don’t need to zero swerve modules If your mechanism has a magnetic encoder, you can ignore it for now, but you will want to add that functionality in later Most motors have a setPosition or a setSensorPosition method Make a method in your Arm class called ‘resetSensorPosition’ Make it set the motor/sensor position to the min angle constant (or whatever angle you prefer to zero it to) Another method you may want is ‘setNeutralMode’ with a parameter for the neutral mode (brake or coast) This will set the motor config to have a selected neutral mode This is very useful for when a technician wants to freely move a robot mechanism around while the robot is disabled Write the ‘setNeutralMode’ method Here is an example of the setNeutralMode method for CTRE It returns a boolean for whether the status of the motor is okay For the angular velocity mechanism slides I am going to refer to an intake If you aren’t using an intake, replace where I say ‘intake’ with whatever your mechanism is Many teams simply set a voltage for their intake (or flywheel) to run at when intaking and shooting gamepieces They then tune that voltage based on how gamepieces react There are a couple major flaws When resistance comes to a voltage controlled mechanism, it will slow the mechanism. We want consistent speed. Controlling things with velocity allows us to have fine control over its speed rather than guessing with voltage There are situations where you may want open loop voltage control (e.g. grabbing algae off the reef in 2025). However, these are pretty niche. For velocity control, you can’t use the same exact logic as you do for a PID Let’s say your velocity is 500 RPM and you want it to be 1000 RPM With a PID, you take the difference and multiply by a constant to get the motor output (ignoring I and D) But imagine what happens as we get closer to 1000 RPM The motor output becomes zero Unfortunately, because of friction and other factors, this means we would never actually reach 1000 RPM The solution to this problem is an SVAP The P constant means the same thing it did in a PID The most important constants in velocity control are V and P The V factor is feedforward V is basically multiplied by the target velocity and added to the total voltage https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/introduction/introduction-to-feedforward.html#introduction-to-dc-motor-feedforward Set your SVAP to a low V (0.02) and 0 for S, A, and P for now in the constructor where you configure the motor If using CTRE, also set motion magic config: https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/latest/docs/api-reference/device-specific/talonfx/motion-magic.html Now we need a method to set the velocity of the intake There is usually a method of the motor object you can call to set the motor velocity For CTRE, you need to give it a control request. There are multiple options for this, but I would suggest a ‘MotionMagicVelocityVoltage’ request Add a GEAR_RATIO constant to an IntakeConstants class in Constants You will most likely need to talk to the designer of your robot intake to get the gear ratio You can configure your motor to know what the gear ratio is: This allows us to put in the intake velocity we want into the ‘setControl’ motor method Now write the method to set the velocity of the intake You will want the input of the method to be in rotations per minute and the input to the motor to be rotations per second, so you will need to convert It should tell the motor to go to that velocity CTRE example: Note: we use the Units Library here The core functionality is now done. In theory, we should be able to turn the intake

docs.title: 4 Advantage Kit/Scope
docs.text: Before we run the mechanism, it is important to be able to read where the robot thinks the mechanism is You could imagine that if you move the elevator an inch and the robot thinks it went 3 inches, it is probable that when you tell the elevator to go to 3 inches it will only go an inch Basically we need to log the state of our mechanisms One way we could read information from the robot is System.out.println() This is used occasionally in FRC for niche purposes However, you could imagine that constantly printing the current positions and velocities of different mechanisms over time to the constant would get extremely annoying We need a way to graph these relationships in an organized fasion There are a couple of solutions for this; the most popular of which is called ‘Advantage Scope’ Advantage Scope allows people to plot values like position and velocity on graphs so we can observe how they change over time in a neater format However, Advantage Scope is far cooler than a graphing software, there are all sorts of ways you can visualize the information coming from your robot For now, lets focus on graphing the position or velocity of our mechanism Before we can do this, we need a way to get the information from the robot to our computer The solution to this is called ‘NetworkTables’ You can almost think of network tables as a bulletin board that both your robot and your computer can post and read information from Each sticky note has a name and a value (just like a variable) In NetworkTables, these sticky notes are called ‘data entries’ or ‘logged data’ And in NetworkTables, these data entries are being updated many times a second Advantage Scope shows you all of the data entries on Network Tables and lets you visualize them Now the question is: how do we get the robot to post to Network Tables so we can read information on Advantage Scope?

docs.title: 4.1 Advantage Kit
docs.text: WPILib has a class for NetworkTables which has all the functionality we need: https://github.wpilib.org/allwpilib/docs/release/java/edu/wpi/first/networktables/NetworkTable.html However, the team that made Advantage Scope, Mechanical Advantage #6328, also created ‘Advantage Kit’ Advantage Kit is basically a library that can be added to FRC code to handle logging data to NetworkTables However, installing Advantage Kit is not as simple as adding another vendor dep There is a way to convert existing projects like ours into advantage kit projects: https://docs.advantagekit.org/getting-started/installation/existing-projects You may go through this process if you’d like However, there are a lot of steps involved and for us it will be simpler to download one of Advantage Kit’s template projects and start from there Download a template project for your robot (based on your type of drivetrain): https://github.com/Mechanical-Advantage/AdvantageKit/releases Here are docs explaining more about template projects: https://docs.advantagekit.org/category/template-projects If you aren’t sure which template to choose, use the vision template Now extract the folder to a new folder (called “FRCSoftwareTrainingAK,” or whatever you like) in the same base directory where your original project is stored Now make that folder into a personal git repository using GitHub CLI Install GitHub CLI: https://cli.github.com/ Create the repo: https://cli.github.com/manual/gh_repo_create The structure of subsystems looks a little different under the Advantage Kit format, but fundamentally it’s the same: Send commands to the motors Read information from the motors Our new version of our subsystem will have 3 layers Top level Subsystem (ex: Elevator.Java) Extends SubsystemBase Abstract IO (ex: ElevatorIO.Java) IO implementation (ex: ElevatorIOReal.Java) Implements abstract IO Follow this format and make these classes for your subsystem (for Elevator.java, use WPILib’s create subsystem functionality) The abstract IO is technically not a class, but an interface, so change that accordingly The top level class is what is called by other classes in the code This is how other parts of the code get information from the mechanism and send information to the mechanism The IO layer (the other two files) can be thought of as one layer This is because the IO implementation or ‘real’ class will implement and therefore become an implementation of the abstract IO layer The job of the real class is to deal with the motor itself The top level will send commands and receive information from the IO layer The reason it is set up this way is so that we can have different implementations of the IO For example, imagine you want to be able to swap out a TalonFX motor for a SparkMAX motor at competition (bad idea, but possible) You could have one IO implementation for TalonFX and one IO implementation for SparkMAX The most common way this structure is used is for simulation You could have an ‘ElevatorIOSim.java’ class as well, which can interact with the simulation The takeaway is that the IO implementation will take methods like ‘setHeight’ that are in the abstract IO and give the functionality for setting the height of the mechanism The top level class will have logic that doesn’t change based on the IO implementation For example, Elevator.java might have a ‘setScoringHeight’ method that calls the ‘setHeight’ method of the IO class with a particular height Additionally, the IO will give information about the motor to the top level class This information can also be automatically logged by Advantage Kit Official information on IO: https://docs.advantagekit.org/data-flow/recording-inputs/io-interfaces Now it’s time to convert our old subsystem into the new format Copy the methods and instance fields from your old subsystem to the ‘Real’ class (except periodic) Rename the constructor Add those methods as abstract methods to the abstract IO class (except the constructor) This will mean removing the logic from the methods as well Now add the @Override keyword before each method in the real class (except constructor) Now add those same methods (except the constructor) to the top-level class Remove all logic from the inside of those methods (Java will get mad, that is okay) Add a constructor to the top level Add an instance field that is the abstract IO class and set it in the constructor with a parameter Now replace method logic with ‘io.[methodName]’ or ‘return io.[methodName]’ Now calling something from the top level will send commands to the bottom level (the IO) Now we need to find a way to log information to NetworkTables so we can view it in Advantage Scope Firstly, lets add a class to the abstract IO which stores the values we want to log Create a subclass called ‘[SubsystemName]Inputs’ in the abstract IO Add variables for the information you want to log This usually includes Device connected? Position Velocity Voltage Current Temperature However, you can tailor it to the mechanism you have Elevator ex: Advantage Kit makes it very easy to log this information Add the keyword @AutoLog before the subclass Elevator ex: Now we need to update the values of the subclass We can do this from the io implementation Create a new method called “updateInputs” in the io implementation which has the subclass as a parameter Add an abstract version of that method to the abstract class Override that abstract method in the io implementation Now update the variables of the inputs subclass in that method using motor methods CTRE Elevator ex: You will need to use StatusSignals if you use CTRE. They are similar to suppliers: https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/stable/docs/api-reference/api-usage/status-signals.html Now you can add a [SubsystemName]Inputs object as an instance field to the top level Then in periodic you can call the UpdateInputs method of the io object using the new inputs object Lastly, lets add methods to get information about our mechanism for other classes in our robot program Add getter methods for position or velocity depending on your mechanism (retrieve this information from the inputs object) Congratulations, your subsystem has been converted into the Advantage Kit format!

docs.title: Advantage Scope Installation
docs.text: Now install Advantage Scope in preparation for reading logged values https://docs.advantagescope.org/overview/installation/

docs.title: 4.3 Units
docs.text: Create a new Constants class for the Drivetrain Add a constant for max speed Print that constant in App.javaStory time! In 1998, Nasa launched a new robotic space probe called “The Mars Climate Orbiter” It cost $125 million (about the same as a modern FRC robot) It was designed to study the Martian atmosphere, the Martian surface, and relay communications Unfortunately, JPL lost control over the robot It disintegrated in the atmosphere :( Why did this happen? Some software provided to NASA by Lockheed martin used US units Other software that used that data created by NASA used imperial units The mismatch in units resulted in disaster This is a mistake that can be made on FRC robots as well So far, we’ve been using inches, radians, radians/second, rotations/minute, ect. One thing we could do is try to stick to one base type of units only (like meters and radians) However, there would be a couple of drawbacks to this We would still need to perform unit conversions when sending information to motors (they only accept values in one type of unit) Using meters might make sense for the distance the robot traveled, but inches would make more sense for the distance the elevator traveled WPILib have created a solution! It is called the Units library: https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/basic-programming/java-units.html The idea is that you can store different physical quantities in objects For example, you can store ‘3 inches’ in a Distance object When you want to get that information back out of the distance object, you will need to specify what units you want it in This way, there aren’t just numbers floating around, there are objects that represent distances, velocities, times, voltages, ect. Here is an example of using the Distance class from the Units library: Notice how the number 3 was encoded with inches, then we converted that Distance object into meters Similar classes exists such as Angle, AngularVelocity, LinearVelocity, and many more You can even create your own units: https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/basic-programming/java-units.html Use the Units class wherever you have a value that represents a physical quantity in your subsystem Note that you will probably want to keep the values in the Inputs class as doubles because that way they will be logged in the units of your preference, rather than logged as objects

docs.title: 4.4 Tunable Numbers
docs.text: Remember how we are going to use a PID (or an SVAP for velocity mechanisms) When we start testing our code on the physical robot, we’ll want to tweak these values a lot to create a smooth motion The problem is that it isn’t as simple as tweaking the number in code and observing the results on the robot Every time we write new code on our computers, we need to redeploy that code to the robot, this will cause the robot software to restart, which can take a while This would make tweaking those values a nightmare CTRE has a very elegant solution to this In Pheonix Tuner X, you can adjust these values on the fly However To my knowledge, it is not this easy for REV There will certainly be other values in the code that you want to tweak quickly outside of motor configs Thankfully, Team #6328 has our backs again They’ve created a class called LoggedTunableNumber in their robot code libraries: https://github.com/Mechanical-Advantage/RobotCode2025Public/blob/main/src/main/java/org/littletonrobotics/frc2025/util/LoggedTunableNumber.java There are a couple places you can import this file in your code My team creates a folder in the frc directory called lib Inside that folder we create another folder called team[team number] Inside that folder, we import the files Import the LoggedTunableNumber class You will need to change the package declaration You can choose to create constants to replace the constants that existed in their project or to remove the use of those constants in the LoggedTunableNumber class Now create instance fields for your subsystem that represent the tunable numbers for the P, I, and D (or VSAP if you have an angular vel mech) Currently we simply set the PID when we construct the subsystem We need a way to update the PID whenever we change the tunable numbers For this, create a method that sets the config values of the PID/SVAP in the io (making sure to add an abstract version in the abstract io) CTRE ex: Now in the periodic method of the top-level you can use this logic to check if the tunable numbers have changed and update them accordingly: Now that you have a setConstants method, you can add that to the constructor, so it runs at the start of the program You can also remove the PID configs from the constructor in the IOReal class

docs.title: 4.5 Sensors
docs.text: Your subsystem may or may not have a sensor If it does, you can read from that sensor and log the value, just like how you read information from the motor and log it Find the documentation for your specific sensor and find out how to read information from it Add a field to your Inputs subclass for that information Update that field in the UpdateInputs method You can also add a getter to your top level for this information Congratulations! Your subsystem code should now meet the standards of a lot of high-level teams. Note, there is likely a lot of code in your subsystem now; use comments to organize things and make things understandable to collaborators:

docs.title: 5 Commands
docs.text: Before we can start testing our code on the robot, we need a way to tell the subsystem what to do based on inputs from an Xbox controller This is called a “Command” Commands have subsystems as instance fields and call methods of the subsystems during their runtimes You could imagine that a complex action like scoring a gamepiece could take complex choreography between the drivetrain, indexer, shooter, and vision system Commands store this choreography

docs.title: 5.1 Creating Commands
docs.text: To make a command, right click on the ‘commands’ folder and click “create a new class or command”, then choose command Name it based on your mechanism (setElevatorHeight, setShooterVelocity, setArmAngle) Now pass in your subsystem as a parameter and create an instance field for your subsystem Call the ‘addRequirements’ method in your constructor and pass in your subsystem This tells the robot code to reserve control of that subsystem to that command, so you don’t get multiple commands controlling the same subsystem at the same time You will notice a few pre-generated methods These relate to the choreography and timing of how your command runs They will be called by the command scheduler behind the scenes Read the comments to understand how each method is called For our purposes, using the ‘initialize’ and ‘end’ methods will suffice We want to start the mechanism when the command is initialized (button pressed) and end it when the command ends (button lifted) In ‘initialize’ call your subsystem’s set-position or set-velocity method (create a constructor parameter and instance field for the position/velocity) In ‘end’ call your subsystem’s ‘setVoltage’ method and set the voltage to zero

docs.title: 5.2 Running Commands
docs.text: Now we need to bind this command to a button on the controller This is where the ‘RobotContainer’ class comes in Open that class/file There should already be an xbox controller object instance field: There is also a spot for subsystem instance fields: Add your subsystem as an instance field Now we need to instantiate the subsystem in the constructor You will notice a switch case in the constructor for the robot type: In the real case, simply construct your subsystem using the top level subsystem constructor and the IOReal constructor inside of that There is also a sim case. Usually in this case, we would pass in an IOSim class; however, we have not written code for that yet, so we are going to pass in a “fake” implementation To pass in a “fake” implementation, call the top level constructor and pass in ‘new [subsystem name]IO(){}’ This creates an implementation of the IO class with no logic. So nothing will happen when your code tries to use this implementation. Do the same for the default case You will notice that at the end of the RobotContainer constructor the ‘setButtonBindings’ method is called This method tells the Xbox controller object what code to call when a button is pressed At the end of that method you can add a binding for your command using this logic: Make sure your binding doesn’t conflict with other bindings If we have a mechanism that needs to be zeroed (angular position or linear position), then we need to create a button for that too You could imagine this would not be a good button to have on the Xbox controller (wouldn’t want to accidentally zero the robot during a match) Many high-level teams have a physical button on their robot for this If you have this on your robot, create a digital input that zeroes the robot: https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/hardware-apis/sensors/digital-inputs-software.html Having a zero button and a brake/coast mode toggle button physically on the robot was a lifesaver for my team. Your team should highly consider adding these to their next robot.

docs.title: 5.3 Elastic
docs.text: If you don’t, we just need to create a button that we can press from our laptops WPILib’s solution for this is called “Shuffleboard” Team 353 made a better version of Shuffleboard called “Elastic” https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/dashboards/elastic.html Download elastic Elastic is geared towards being a dashboard for behind the glass (at the driver station) However, it is also a useful programmer’s tool Let’s create a button we can press in elastic that will zero the robot To create a button, this is the format: ‘SmartDashboard.putData’ takes in two parameters The name of the button A command to run when the button is pressed Notice how I didn’t create a new command class for zeroing the elevator Commands.runOnce will take in a supplier to be ran when the command is initialized In this case, I created a method in the elevator class that sets the sensor position to a ‘home position’ (for you this will probably be zero, it should be the place that the mechanism usually rests in. You will need to put the mechanism in this position before pressing the zero button). Create your zero button Create a brake mode and coast mode button

docs.title: 5.4 Running the Mech
docs.text: It’s finally time to run the code on the robot and see if our mechanism works This is where we need to be very careful because it is usually possible to damage the robot by having mechanisms whack each other or by burning out motors When you first run a mechanism, run it very slowly and for short periods of time To start we need to deploy our code to the robot Turn on your robot and connect to it Now open the command pallet and run ‘deploy robot code’ If you get a message like ‘build failed’, look at the stack trace and try to figure out what is wrong with the code Usually, it is syntax errors or small mistakes Sometimes you can find other people experiencing similar issues on Chief Delphi (the FRC forum) Once your code is deployed, open advantage scope and plot your mechanism position or veloctity on a line graph (note: you may need to set your team # in advantage scope before it will connect, it’s the same with elastic) Sometimes code repeatedly crashes once deployed to the robot This can happen for a couple reasons: Code issues (such as null pointer) -> check stack trace of crash and find code bug Firmware issues -> your roborio, PDH, motor controllers, motors, CANivore, or sensors may be out of date, make sure to update all physical components If your mechanism needs to be zeroed: Open Elastic and find your button in the widget menu Drag it onto the screen Do the same for brake mode and coast mode Try manually moving the physical mechanism to zero and pressing the button Advantage scope should log the mechanism being at zero Now let’s do a sanity check Try moving your mechanism to a different position (or spinning it if it’s an angular velocity mech) Advantage scope should log a reasonable value If it’s a linear position mech, measure the distance you moved it If it’s an angular position mech, estimate the angle you moved it If it’s an angular vel mech, you shouldn’t get anything over 100 rpm, but you should get some rpm If Advantage Scope’s logged value matches your physical observation, you are on the right track If not, you may want to check your conversion math in the subsystem code It’s finally time to start moving the mechanism If you are using CTRE, I would highly suggest using Pheonix tuner X’s native tools for tuning: https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/stable/docs/tuner/controlling-devices.html If you are using REV, this is why we have tunable numbers in our code For instructions on tuning your mechanism: 5.4.A: Position Mech 5.4.B: Velocity Mech For position mechanisms, the first step is almost always to tune the G constant (unless your mechanism is linear and perfectly horizontal, is light enough to not be concerned with gravity or rotates about the x-y plane) Remember, G is the amount of power the motor always puts out to resist gravity Make sure the gravity type is correct in your code if using CTRE For linear mechanisms, we can always put out the same voltage to resist gravity For rotating mechanism, like an arm, we need more power when the arm is horizontal than straight up. The power we need is proportional to cos(Ѳ) CTRE will do these calculations automatically for the g constant. To my knowledge, for REV you will need pass in a tunable amount as a feedforward: https://docs.revrobotics.com/revlib/spark/closed-loop/getting-started-with-pid-tuning If using REV and an arm, you will need to take cos(Ѳ) into account manually Now try setting g to incrementally bigger values (after setting all other constants to 0) while being in the position control mode The goal is for the mechanism to start moving very very slowly; once you reach this, go back to the last value where it didn’t NOTE: You may have the WRONG invert on your motor, if the motor is trying to spin the wrong direction, stop the motor, flip your invert before something breaks. If you are using an arm, make sure the arm is able to hold its position at all angles Now up the P constant to a small value Keep upping it until the mechanism goes to the target position you set in code Note: if using CTRE you may need to have non-zero values for max velocity and target acceleration before it will move Once it does, set the voltage to 0, let the mechanism go limp, and turn position control back on Take a look at advantage scope and observe how the position approaches the target position If you are using an arm, make sure the arm is able to hold its position at all angles Now up the P constant to a small value Keep upping it until the mechanism goes to the target position you set in code Once it does, set the voltage to 0, let the mechanism go limp, and turn position control back on Take a look at advantage scope and observe how the position approaches the target position It should look like one of the lines on the graph (the blue one is the target position If your graph looks like the red one, keep increasing the P constant and repeating the trial until you overshoot, then go back to the last non-overshooting P value If your graph looks like the green one or the purple one, your P is too high; lower it until it doesn’t overshoot You can also try tuning the I and D constants for even smoother motion: https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/introduction/introduction-to-pid.html#introduction-to-pid If using CTRE motion magic, you should also tune max velocity and target acceleration In general, the voltage you put into your velocity motor is proportional the velocity it will go at This is why the V constant will be the most important constant to tune Increase your V value until your mechanism reaches your target velocity (eventually) after putting it into velocity control mode Note: if using CTRE Motion Magic, your target acceleration needs to be non-zero You can check this by looking at the velocity in Advantage Scope We can make this snappier Your velocity should follow a path similar to the red line on the right The blue line is the target velocity Start increasing the P constant until you overshoot velocity a little bit like the green line, then go back to the last non-overshooting value If using CTRE Motion magic, try adjusting your acceleration as well You can also play around with the S and A constants: Now your mechanism should get to its target velocity in a reasonable time For an intake, this time needs to be very short For a shooter, depending on how it’s used, it can take longer to spool up to full speed If applicable, try putting a game piece through your mechanism (safely and with a mentor/adult) See if the velocity drops noticeably as it goes through If the velocity drops quite a bit, especially for an intake/shooter, this is not ideal This either means, the mechanism needs to be tuned more or there is physically not enough power or Moment of Inertia to maintain target velocity. It can also mean a bad physical gear ratio. This is absolutely something to talk to mechanics about.

docs.title: 5.5 Next Steps
docs.text: Once you have your mechanism smoothly reaching its target position and velocity, try a couple other positions and velocities, make sure those work as expected as well Congratulations, you have written subsystem code, command code, binded a function to an Xbox controller button, and tuned/tested the subsystem I would HIGHLY suggest going through this whole process for the other two types of mechanisms as well if you have them on your robot. If you do this, you will learn the nuances of these other mechanisms and have subsystem code for complex subsystem choreography later. Trust me, it will be a lot faster now that you’ve done it before

docs.title: 6 Drivetrain
docs.text: In almost every FRC game, a robot that doesn’t move doesn’t contribute to the alliance (often, a non-moving robot contributes negatively to the alliance) Getting the software for the drivetrain correct is pivotal in team competitiveness Even having one match where your robot doesn’t move can dramatically effect which teams will pick you in alliance selection Additionally, when drivetrain design and code is done very well, it gives that team an exceptional advantage over other teams There are 3 primary forms of drivetrains in modern FRC The first is called tank drive Tank drive is generally the cheapest Two sides of wheels are independently driven If both sides go forward, the robot goes forward If one goes forward and one goes backward, the robot turns It is also known as ‘differential drive’ The second is called mecanum With mecanum, there are four modules Each module has it’s own motor and can be driven independently Through a bunch of interesting science that isn’t super necessary to understand, this allows forward motion, backward motion, sideways motion, and rotating The improvement from tank is that mecanum allows for side-to-side motion Mecanum is also fairly cheap The main issues with mecanum are that your robot can be pushed around easily Your robot will not deal with bumps well Your robot will have trouble accelerating and changing direction quickly (especially side-to-side) Swerve involves four modules (like mecanum) Each individual module has a wheel that can change it’s direction and angular velocity In one module, one motor determines the direction of the wheel, one motor determines the angular velocity of the wheel This allows for side-to-side motion, forward backward motion, and rotational motion It also allows for incredible accelerations, stability, and bumps The only downside is the price. A single top of the line FRC swerve module from the best company for swerve (SDS) will run your team back $395 (2025 numbers) You need 4 of those and 8 motors That is a lot of money Having a good finance subteam is very important Consider reaching out to SDS for a sponsorship There are also other quality models of swerve on the market such as MK4, MAXswerve, and Swerve X which are somewhat cheaper Swerve has established itself as the dominant drive train in FRC in recent years If your team does not currently use swerve, it is a great direction to move in for competitiveness Before diving into the specifics of each type of drivetrain, it is also helpful to learn about different ways to control robot movement There are two main ways: Robot-centric Field-centric Robot-Centric means that “forward” on the stick means move whichever way the robot is facing This can become confusing quickly as the robot rotates a lot on the field and the driver needs to keep track of which way is “forward” The better and more modern way to drive is called “field-centric” Field centric means that pressing forward on the stick will drive the robot away from the driver on the field (toward the opposing field wall) This won’t change even if the robot rotates This relies on the robot knowing which way it is facing so it can correct for its own rotation when the driver wants it to move in a particular direction This means that field-centric robots need an IMU (basically a gyro) to keep track of their rotation Note that IMUs are relative. They actually track angular acceleration rather than angular position but are able to convert acceleration to position. This means that similar to needing to tell an elevator when its at zero position and zeroing it, you will need to tell the robot what orientation it is in at the start of a match. Ideally, you will also have a button to re-zero the robot orientation if needed WPILib has also introduced a standard way to tell a drivetrain subsystem how to act This is called a ChassisSpeeds object The ChassisSpeeds object stores 3 values X velocity (left right) Y velocity (forward backward) Omega (angular vel) This information can be sent to the drivetrain as a command and received from the drivetrain as logged data Identify what drivetrain your robot has (if you have a robot) Go to the corresponding section for your drivetrain 6.A: Swerve 6.B: Mecanum 6.C: Differential (Tank)

docs.title: 6.1 Swerve
docs.text: If your project is based off the Advantage Kit swerve template, you are in a good place If not, download the swerve template and move your subsystem code, commands, and button bindings into a swerve template Make sure to download the correct template for your motor types I could explain how to get your drivetrain up and running in this slideshow, but I would be directly repeating what 6328 has already documented Follow the setup instructions for your swerve template project: https://docs.advantagekit.org/category/template-projects Once you have it set up, try running your drivetrain and moving your robot (with proper safety precautions) If it’s not working, you can check logged values on advantage scope to help debug the issue. You should also make sure all of your swerve motors are up to date and CAN IDed correctly. I would highly encourage looking through the template swerve code to find out how it works Note that with swerve, there is a high-level drive subsystem as well as lower-level swerve module subsystems Look for things like Where are methods for turning motors How is a field-oriented x-y-omega (ChassisSpeeds) object converted into individual motor commands Many high-level teams make their own additions and modifications to their drive subsystem to meet their needs As you gain experience as a programmer, you may have changes in mind as well

docs.title: Mecanum
docs.text: Mecanum is a little tricky, because there isn’t a template project provided by Advantage Kit specifically for mecanum However, there are libraries in WPILib for running Mecanum code: https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/kinematics-and-odometry/mecanum-drive-kinematics.html You will need to either use the Vision Template or the Skeleton Template (if your code is not currently in one of these, you can either remove the current drive code in your codebase or move your new code to one of these templates) Each mecanum wheel is its own module with its own wheel. In this case, it can be helpful to think of each module as its own subsystem with its own logged values and methods Remember a mecanum module is an angular velocity mechanism, but it can also provide linear velocity information based on how fast the circumference of the wheel is moving (radius * omega radians) Then, a Drive subsystem can be created with an array of four mecanum subsystem objects inside of it. The Drive subsystem will convert ChassisSpeeds into individual module outputs using WPILib’s MecanumDriveKinematics. Using WPILib’s mecanum libraries, your drive subsystem should be able to convert a ChassisSpeeds object into method calls to individual module subsystems For further reference on how to code a mecanum drivetrain, check out the swerve templates for advantage kit. Both mecanum and swerve work with individual modules and ChassisSpeeds objects. For driving field-centric, you will need a gyro (IMU) subsystem as well. You will need a command that takes Suppliers from the xbox sticks and converts them to method calls to the drive subsystem (generally, left stick is movement, right is rotation). Reference the swerve template for an example of this. Get your robot moving!

docs.title: Differential (Tank)
docs.text: If your project is based off the Advantage Kit differential drive template, you are in a good place If not, download the differential drive template and move your subsystem code, commands, and button bindings into it I could explain how to get your drivetrain up and running in this slideshow, but I would be directly repeating what 6328 has already documented Follow the setup instructions for your diffy drive template project: https://docs.advantagekit.org/category/template-projects Once you have it set up, try running your drivetrain and moving your robot (with proper safety precautions) If it’s not working, you can check logged values on advantage scope to help debug the issue. You should also make sure all of your swerve motors are up to date and CAN IDed correctly.

docs.text: Text

docs.text:
If your project is based off the Advantage Kit swerve template, you are in a good place If not, download the swerve template and move your subsystem code, commands, and button bindings into a swerve template Make sure to download the correct template for your motor types

I could explain how to get your drivetrain up and running in this slideshow, but I would be directly repeating what 6328 has already documented Follow the setup instructions for your swerve template project: https://docs.advantagekit.org/category/template-projects Once you have it set up, try running your drivetrain and moving your robot (with proper safety precautions) If it’s not working, you can check logged values on advantage scope to help debug the issue. You should also make sure all of your swerve motors are up to date and CAN IDed correctly.

I would highly encourage looking through the template swerve code to find out how it works Note that with swerve, there is a high-level drive subsystem as well as lower-level swerve module subsystems Look for things like Where are methods for turning motors How is a field-oriented x-y-omega (ChassisSpeeds) object converted into individual motor commands Many high-level teams make their own additions and modifications to their drive subsystem to meet their needs As you gain experience as a programmer, you may have changes in mind as well
